utterances: With his appointments, his reaching out efforts to everybody.
I agree.
He's a good candidate.
Sean, thanks very much.
Appreciate it.
Thank you so much.
Let's see if we get one last caller in.
Let's go to Cleve(ph), Cleve with us from North Augustus in South Carolina.
Yes.
How're you doing?
Very well.
Thank you.

Yes, I'm calling in as a black Republican, but I'm also a conservative on social issues, and I just disagree with the idea that the Republican needs to become some type of broader tent, a sort of a Democrat-lite type of situation.
I think the Republicans lose anytime we put a candidate who is a moderate on the ticket, like McCain was, and it doesn't have a rallying cry for the vast majority Republicans who are conservative.
As a black man, I'm conservative anyway.
I think most polls show that blacks traditionally are more conservative on the issues.
They may identify with the Democratic Party, but their values are very traditional.
That's why like in California, the additional blacks who registered to vote, voted for Proposition 8, I believe, because they were traditional in values even though they were Democrats.
That, of course was, the gay marriage ban.
Right.
And I say, I disagree with the speaker, with Sophia, that the direction we need to go is to be so-called broader.

I think we need to be clearer in our focus, and I think traditionally our focus, which - by the way, Reagan was very conservative - gives a greater rally in cry for those of us who are conservative, whether we're black, Mexican or whatever.
Sophia Nelson, you've got 45 seconds.
(LAUGHTER)
Well, clearly, I respect that the caller's point of view but he's just wrong.
If the party continues to go in the direction it's going in, it's going to become a regional party relegated to minority status in leadership and in national elections for a long time to come.
The country is browning.
By 2020 and 2025, it's going to be already - it's already close to majority people of color, but it will be majority people of color in the next 10 years or so.
And you cannot win elections, national elections, with a myopic message that focuses on abortion, guns and gay marriage.
I'm conservative, too.
I may agree with him probably on most of those issues, but I don't think they belong in our politics.
Cleve, thanks very much for the call.
I appreciate it.
Thank you.
So long, and Sophia Nelson, thank you for being on the Opinion Page today.
Thank you for having me.
Sophia Nelson is a lawyer and the editor of politicalintersectionblog.com - I got it right that time - as well as a former Republican congressional staffer.
She joined us here in Studio 3A.
Tomorrow on Talk of the Nation, Bob Woodward on the Bush legacy.
Join us.
This is Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
This is DAY TO DAY, I'm Alex Chadwick.
Along the Gulf Coast no date looms in the distance with more foreboding than June 1st.
That's the beginning of hurricane season.
So much is still not ready.
Half the houses in New Orleans remain empty.
Some are gutted, some not.
One family living in one of the area's worst hit neighborhoods though is planting pansies outdoors.
The Riccas live in Lakeview and they are just about ready for hurricane season at their place.
Angelo Ricca joins us from there.
Hello Angelo, welcome to the program.
How you doing?
I'm well, thank you.

You have moved from Riverbend, one of the neighborhoods that stayed safe through everything, to a place that's almost right next to the 17th Street Canal, which is really where the flooding began, isn't that so?
Yes sir, we're about a half a block from the canal, between the canal and Fleur-de-lis.
Why would you do such a thing?
I like taking chances, I guess.
The house is a gorgeous house and we have armed guards patrolling all the time, so it's a secure area.
It's in a real nice neighborhood and I honestly believe it will never happen again.
This is something that happens once every hundred years or so.
And I lost one other house in the storm, but I always have to be doing something.
What kind of shape was the house in when you bought it?
It had nine foot of water in it.
And what have you done to the place to transform it?
Mainly, the first thing we did before we even worked on the inside, we planted flowers and got rid of all the dead plants and tried to make the place look more presentable outside for eye appeal.
And then we just started working on the inside.
It was all gutted and we had to rewire it and sheetrocked it and put all new doors in, and it looks real nice.
So look, you've put in leaded glass in this house.
Yes.
Crown moldings.
Oh yes.
Crystal chandelier.
Yes, two of them.
Hardwood floors.
No, sir.
No.
We have stone floors and carpet.
Well, are you worried that another storm might take all that out?
I'll do it again.
So you're going to stay?
Yes, sir.
Well, what does your wife think about living beside the 17th Street Canal?
She loves the house.
Well, I guess she loves the house, but does she love the location?
Yes, because she was from Metairie and I was from New Orleans all my life, and people here just kind of stay in their own neighborhoods forever, I think.
Was there a time ever in the last six months where you thought to yourself, I just have to move on, this is not going to be the place for us anymore?
